stories.text:
With smartphones becoming evermore accessible, they’ve become more versatile as well. GPS, flashlights, camera, pedometer, I could spend all day listing things it has replaced.

What about coding, not typing into a text editor, but an interactive touch screen environment so users can piece together procedures, library calls etc.

It’s be attempted in the past and has failed. You could easily argue it’s nowhere near as productive. But maybe that’s because programming languages need to move away from touch based environments.
stories.title: Ask HN: Programming on Smartphones
Killed by a pill bought on social media: counterfeit drugs poisoning US teens
Neuroscience says listening to this song reduces anxiety by up to 65%

stories.text:
What technology do you use today that is far from mainstream? Think Tony Stark technology.
Examples are mobile phones / internet in the 80s, metal 3D printers, quantum ML, night vision device, large language models (GPT-3) for personal communication, CRISPR, manned drones.
stories.title: Ask HN: What cutting-edge technology do you use?
Show HN: Typesnd – A simple web app for chatting and sending images
